results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a parade with a marching band through a country town past a garage called Bridge Motors (likely Duigan’s garage in Yarrawonga), followed by a couple in a rowboat and a group of people cavorting on the banks of a river or lake wearing 1920s fashion.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features panoramic views of the Red Rock Lakes near Colac, Victoria. The film features shots of a man and child on a hill, with the man holding a film camera, and shots of Duigan’s brother, Reginald Duigan, and children outside a large house.

results.title: [Ned Kelly cummerbund interview]
results.brief_description:
This collection of films has been generously donated by the Benalla Historical Society. The collection features moments in Benalla’s history and surrounding areas, including visits by the Governor of Victoria Sir Rohan Delacombe, ceremonies revealing various commemorative plaques, and the return of Ned Kelly’s cummerbund, thought to have been lost.

This film shows an interview with a member of the Benalla Historical Society, regarding a green, bloodstained sash or cummerbund worn by Ned Kelly at the Glenrowan siege. The sash was given to Ned at the age of ten by a family whose child Ned saved from drowning. Ned was wearing it at the Glenrowan siege when he was captured in 1880. A doctor who tended to his wounds took it off while Ned was unconscious and kept it. The family later donated the sash in 1973 to the Benalla Historical Society. It is now on display in the Benalla Costume and Kelly Museum.

results.title: [Ned Kelly cummerbund]
results.brief_description:
This collection of films has been generously donated by the Benalla Historical Society. The collection features moments in Benalla’s history and surrounding areas, including visits by the Governor of Victoria Sir Rohan Delacombe, ceremonies revealing various commemorative plaques, and the return of Ned Kelly’s cummerbund, thought to have been lost.

This silent footage shows a member of the Benalla Historical Society displaying the donated original green, bloodstained sash or cummerbund worn by Ned Kelly at the Glenrowan siege. The sash was given to Ned at the age of ten by a family whose child Ned saved from drowning. He was wearing it at the Glenrowan siege when captured in 1880. A doctor who tended to his wounds took it off while Ned was unconscious and kept it. The family then donated the sash in 1973 to the Benalla Historical Society. It is now on display in the Benalla Costume and Kelly Museum.

This film, likely captured for the purpose of editing, corresponds with interview footage of a news story for GMV-6 Shepparton.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:25:00 A member of the Benalla Historical Society presents the green sash
00:00:53:00 Close up showing supposed bloodstains
00:01:25:00 The member demonstrates how the sash is put on and worn
00:02:09:00 The member shows an old photograph of a man, perhaps the doctor who tended to Ned’s wounds
00:02:43:00 The member shows a violin made by John Nicholson in Benalla in 1905

results.title: [Proclamation of Benalla, 1965]
results.brief_description:
This collection of films has been generously donated by the Benalla Historical Society. The collection features moments in Benalla’s history and surrounding areas, including visits by the Governor of Victoria Sir Rohan Delacombe, ceremonies revealing various commemorative plaques, and the return of Ned Kelly’s cumberbund, thought to have been lost.

This film shows proceedings and ceremonies of the Proclamation of Benalla, and the 1965 Miss City of Benalla beauty contest. It features interesting shots of fashion and cars and formal proceedings.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:00:13:00 Unknown VIP arrives in a Rolls Royce, greeted by the Mayor, most likely at the Town Hall. Many members of the general public have gathered.
00:01:11:00 The VIP addresses the crowds gathered
00:02:00:00 Formal proceedings take place inside; great shot of four older woman featuring fashion of the time
00:02:16:00 Cuts to outdoors on an oval; a brass band and assembly of school children of varying ages have gathered; VIP riding in the back of a jeep to greet the students
00:03:32:00 The VIP officially opens the Benalla and District Memorial Hospital
00:03:54:00 Cuts to an upward view of a chandelier; the beginnings of Miss City of Benalla beauty contest; great examples of glamour fashion
00:05:34:00 And the winner is number 16
00:06:17:00 Dancing at a ball

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Titled Walking to School.
This could possibly be an Eaglehawk Primary School Production.

This narrative film follows the eventful journey of a young school boy as he walks to school along a country road. On the way he is joined by school friends and we see their encounters with a variety of native Australian Wildlife. They see lace monitor tracks and follow them to where the monitor is scaling a tree. They also find a possum and an echidna. The film shows various closeups of the animals and the children’s faces as they squint and shield their eyes from the sun.

The children cross a wooden bridge where they meet an old man carrying a swag and a billy. The man gathers the children around him and reads a story to them called “The Bear”. The film then shows us the story as it is being told. It is a tale of a young girl who is very poor, very dirty and very sad. One day she finds a toy koala which brings her great joy. Excitedly she tries to show her Koala to other school children who are playing games in the school yard. They ridicule her and throw sticks at her. She runs away and falls on the grass where she drifts off to sleep. She dreams that she is rescued by a fairy Godmother who transforms her into a very clean girl in a beautiful dress! During this sequence we see good examples of Super 8 “special effects” as the fairy works her magic on the other children, transforming them into characters in fancy dress. We see these children playing circle games and closeups of their faces. Eventually the poor girl wakes up to find a kind school boy standing over her. He helps her to her feet, takes her hand and leads her to join his other friends. Together the group skip happily all the way to school along a country road.

This film shows good examples of children’s fashion, games and faces. We also see footage of houses and streets of the time.

Selected Highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:06:00 Title card ‘Walking to School’
00:00:30:00 Goanna climbing tree
00:02:23:00 Echidna
00:03:45:00 Kids story time reading from ‘The Bear’

results.title: [Royal District Nursing Service TV Ad]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

This television advertisement is an appeal for donations to the Royal District Nursing Service. Filmed in black and white, the advertisement shows a nurse visiting various patients in the community, including babies, the elderly, disabled and blind. A voiceover describes the valuable contribution the nurses make to the community, with over 300,000 visits per year - enough patients to fill the largest public hospital.

results.title: [Mental Hygiene Authority 1961]
results.brief_description:
This film was made by the Mental Hygiene Authority of Victoria (later the Mental Health Authority), of which psychiatrist Eric Cunningham Dax was the inaugural Chairman. Dax was an advocate for greater community engagement with mental health and the introduction of art and education programs within psychiatric care. During his tenure, he implemented widespread reform of mental health institutions.

This film shows scenes at the Oakleigh Retarded Childrens Centre, the Oakleigh Sheltered Workshop and the Larundel Psychiatric Hospital. In the film, we see developmentally and intellectually disabled children and adults engaged in activities in the centres including learning how to weave using looms and working on items such as shoelaces and hubcaps in workshop environements. We also see patients of the psychiatric hospital working and playing table tennis.

During his tenure, he implemented widespread reform of mental health institutions.

This film shows scenes at the Oakleigh Retarded Childrens Centre, the Oakleigh Sheltered Workshop and the Larundel Psychiatric Hospital. In the film, we see developmentally and intellectually disabled children and adults engaged in activities in the centres including learning how to weave using looms and working on items such as shoelaces and hubcaps in workshop environements. We also see patients of the psychiatric hospital working and playing table tennis.
description_for_label:
This film was made by the Mental Hygiene Authority of Victoria (later the Mental Health Authority), of which psychiatrist Eric Cunningham Dax was the inaugural Chairman. Dax was an advocate for greater community engagement with mental health and the introduction of art and education programs within psychiatric care. During his tenure, he implemented widespread reform of mental health institutions.

This film shows scenes at the Oakleigh Retarded Childrens Centre, the Oakleigh Sheltered Workshop and the Larundel Psychiatric Hospital. In the film, we see developmentally and intellectually disabled children and adults engaged in activities in the centres including learning how to weave using looms and working on items such as shoelaces and hubcaps in workshop environements. We also see patients of the psychiatric hospital working and playing table tennis.

results.title: [District Nursing Appeal]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.
